description.narrative:
Arua District Blind Women Association is registered CBO (796) located in Arua. Blind women and women with disabilities in Arua are the physically impaired; deaf; blind; mentally handicapped; epileptic little people, etc. They suffer double tragedy: as women in patriarchal society and as women with disabilities. They are very vulnerable: always stigmatised, isolated, discriminated and deprivedof development opportunities, hence remain in the vicious cycle of poverty.
This project aims to promote empowering women with disabilities with appropriate skills to identify and engage in viable self-hep initiatives which can improve their lives. The project targets one hundred and twenty (120) poor rural women with disabilities in Arua districts. The main activities of the projects are: (i) Entrepreneurial and leadership skills training, (ii) Essential reproductive health and Advocacy and Lobby skills training and (iii) Training of duty bearers and community leaders in the district on essential skills of uplifting women with disabilities in the district. The 12 months project will be led by Arua blind women#s association based in Arua .
Overall goal: Realising that majority of women with disabilities in Arua are; stigmatised, isolated, discriminated and deprived of development opportunities, this project therefore visualises improved conditions of living of the poor, rural women with disabilities through self#help development initiative. The project envisages that at least 70 % of the women trained wouldreport that their conditions of living have improved by the end of project period.
Specific Objective: 1. To build and strengthen the capacity of 200 women and Girls with disabilities on Life skills in relation to advocacy and their Rights. 2. To strengthen Institutional capacity of Arua Blind Association to amplify the voices of women and girls with disabilities in the selected sub counties in the Arua District . 3. To create awareness of the selected communities on disability and rights of womenand girls with disabilities to participate in the district and sub-county planningprocess.

participating-org.narrative: Arua District Blind Women Associati ADBWA

Arua District Blind Women Association is a registered non-profit making group which has promoted, economic empowered for women withdisability to live with dignity, Unity, regular meetings, close monitoring have made us successful. We have learned that we have to stick together, share experiences and meet regularly, we are also guided by our Constitution.
Vision: #Independent and self-reliant blind women in Arua District# Mission: #To promote livelihood and expose plights and potentials of the BlindWomen of Arua District so as to receive support and recognition in the communities#
Arua District Blind Women Association therefore exists to influence the inclusion of the needs and issues of PWDs in plans, budget and programme implementation and service delivery by all service providers so that PWDs can access services just like any other people who access them. Main programs or activities include: Disability Rights awareness creation programs/activities, Advocacy programs/activities to promote the rights to access service by PWDs (like education and Health services among others), provision of Sustainable livelihood and skills development programs to improve the socio-economic Status of PWDs.
Arua District Blind women Association embraces the principle of inclusion in all its dimensions, and upholds diversity in delivery of the programmes. We are in the process of developing the HIV and Aids workplace policy to support girls and blind women. Arua District Blind women association in respect with recruitment has Human Resource policy which guides the recruitment of its staff contributing to fair and equitable recruitment processes. For example, 80% of the Arua District Blind women association are girls and women with disabilities.
2. ACHIEVEMENTS What have been the principal results in the past three years that contribute to significant, structural, sustained and positive improvement in the lives of men, women, girls and boys suffering from poverty, injustice, insecurity and exclusion?
Over a period of 8 years, ADDWA has positioned itself as a reliable partner; a) Advocacy;Arua District Blind Women Association has positioned itself as a reliable partner amplifying the voices of blind women in the district through advocacy. For instance through Advocacy Arua District provided assorted seedlings to blind women, through advocacy , Blind women are represented on the District Council for Disability and soon an ordinance will be enacted for accessibility for people with disabilities
b) Livelihood/economic empowerment: Working with ABillis Foundation, Arua District Blind women association has been able to train, mentor and support 12 blind women with entrepreneurial skills and start-up capital. This has enabled them earn anincome and livelihood and this has uplifted their standard of living, they are respected and their confidence built.
c) Establishment of Saving Scheme Arua District Blind women Association started VSLA. Members noted the need to pull resources together through VSLA. The group has 30 members and they are actively saving to invest. The importance of this is that Blind women meet to save, sharetheir experience, uplift and encourage each other for the betterment of their lives. This has enabled the group to grow and jointlyadvocate. d) Networking: Arua District Blind women Association, this has scored tremendously for instance the association has worked with Rotary Club Arua which delivered 20 assistive devices, closely worked with Community Development Departmentof Arua to deliver UWEP to blind association in one of the sub counties. Networked with Finn church Aid to mentor and coach blind students in Refugee camp and Host communities e) Participation in awareness event, Arua District Blind Association has represented the District and Blind women during the National Women#s day, International day of the Disabled, HIV and Aids day, Youth day, among others. These aimat building the capacity of young men and women to be the leaders of tomorrow by empowering them with life skills that enable them to be responsible young men and women first as individual, family and community members. f) Monthly meetings: Arua District Blind Association has been able to hold monthly meetings among members and the top leadershipof the organisation. This has further strengthened the networking, group cohesion and working together.
3. INSTITUTIONAL PURPOSE
Arua District Blind Women Association is a registered non-profit making group which has promoted, economic empowered for women with disability to live with dignity, unity, regular meetings, close monitoring have made us successful. We have learned that we have to stick together, share experiences and meet regularly, we are also guided by our Constitution.
Vision: #Independent and self-reliant blind women in Aura District# Mission: #To promote livelihood and expose plights and potentials of the Blind Women of Arua District so as to receive support and recognition in thecommunities
Institutional objectives: What arethe principal changes the organisation seeks to achieve over the long term? Arua District Blind women Association believes that investments in Blind women#s potential to spur social and economic development, shiftingsocial power relations, and assuringan enabling environment in order for the poor and blind women marginalized households to attainfood security and sustainable resilient livelihoods will empower and liberate disabled people from poverty. In this regard, Arua District Blind women associationstrives for independent living Uganda seeks to contribute to sustainable improvements in the socio-economic and ecological conditions, as a basis of ensuring dignity, wellbeing and resilience of its membership. Arua principally operates in all sub counties of Arua including the refugee camps. The social actors benefiting from Arua District Blind Women Associationwork include; women, youth, People with disabilities, men who are marginalised and have their voices not heard in the development process.
4. STRATEGIC POSITIONING Analyse the environment in which the organisation works? Who are the other relevant social actors,including government and business, and what roles do they play? #In this context, what is unique about the position of the organisation?
Arua District Blind women Association operates in a relatively stable political climate after post conflict, existence of Local Government structures right to the village level and improved security. However, the area has been affected by the influx of refugees from South Sudan of which there are refugees who are blind and need attention by the association.
Disability is a development issue because of its bidirectional link to poverty; disability may increase the risk of poverty, and povertymay increase the risk ofdisability. A growing body of empirical evidence from across the world indicates that PWDs and their families are more likely to experience eco¬nomic and social difficulties than able bodied.
The onset of disability may lead to poverty and reduced social and economic well-being. The process is often negatively determined by the adverse impact on education, employment, earnings, and increasedexpendi¬tures related to disability.
PWDs are more likely to be unemployed and generally earn less even when employed. Both employment and income rates appear to worsen with the severity of the disability. It is harder for people with disabilities to benefit from development processes and escape from poverty due to discrimination inemployment, limited access to transport, and lack of access to resources to promote self-employ¬ment and livelihood activities.
Children with disabilities are less likely to attend school, thus experiencing limited opportunities for human capital formationand eventually facing reduced employment opportu¬nities and decreased productivity in adult¬hood.
Uganda has an enabling legal and policy environment in relation to disability. The Government of Uganda has developed policies and enacted laws intended to ensure the human rights of PWDs as well as their participation in development programmes.
The Constitution of Uganda (1995) prescribes affirmative action to address the existing imbalances affecting sociallymarginalised groups # including PWDsas itprovides the basis for enactment of laws and policies that address their concerns. The Constitution enjoins fair representation of marginalised groups on all constitutional bodies and recognition of the rights of PWDs to respect and human dignity. Specifically, it has a provision for affirmative action to redress the imbalance faced by PWDs like sign language services for the deaf.
The rights of PWDs are also enshrined in a number of Acts in Uganda. Most importantly in the Personswith Disabilities Act from 2006 which prohibits discrimination of PWDs in terms of access to education, health and employment. In fact, the Act provides comprehensive legal protection for PWDs, aimed at eliminating all forms of discrimination as well as ensuring equal opportunities.
5. FUNCTIONAL ORGANISATIONAL CHART (include below your organisational chart) How are authority and responsibilities structured? For each operational unit, indicate the job titles, number of people in each position, and if they are men or women.
Arua District Blind women Association is local NGO managed by a Baord of Directors who are elected during the general assembly.The select committee of the Board of Directors recruit and appoint the Executive Director and the Executive Director manages the Secretariat and the secretariat is composed of Ayikoru Jean Longo, Female visually impaired has a working experience of six to seven years in the area of advocacy and economic empowerment of persons with disability in Northern Uganda. Osooti Christopher a male, social worker and has volunteered with UNAB, Part time Monitoring and Evaluation Assistant and Bako Hellen, Female, Office attendant andguide.
